articles.headline: Learning to Heal, One Memorial Day at a Time
articles.snippet: Every year for the last four years, the men of the Second Battalion, Fourth Marine Regiment, which fought in Iraq, have visited the grave of a fallen comrade.
articles.abstract: Every year for the last four years, the men of the Second Battalion, Fourth Marine Regiment, which fought in Iraq, have visited the grave of a fallen comrade.
articles.lead_paragraph: PFLUGERVILLE, Tex. — They had no plan, really, just memories. So after a few moments of awkward indecision, the young men ambled single file up to a simple gravestone to pay their respects. Each left behind a red or pale yellow rose, a mumbled word or a salty tear. Lance Cpl. Nickalous N. Aldrich, the stone read. Born Aug. 12, 1983, in Austin. Died Aug. 27, 2004, in Iraq.

articles.headline: $8.5 Billion Deal for Calling Service Presents a Puzzle
articles.snippet: Skype must be able to give Windows and other Microsoft products an edge for Microsoft to justify the $8.5 billion it paid, analysts said.
articles.abstract: Skype must be able to give Windows and other Microsoft products an edge for Microsoft to justify the $8.5 billion it paid, analysts said.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — By some measures, Tony Bates has accomplished a lot at Skype since Microsoft paid $8.5 billion for the Internet calling service.

articles.headline: After Facebook, More Fear of Stock Market
articles.snippet: The financial industry had hoped that Facebook would rekindle ordinary investors’ excitement in stocks. But the Facebook faltering just added to a growing retreat from the stock market.
articles.abstract: The financial industry had hoped that Facebook would rekindle ordinary investors’ excitement in stocks. But the Facebook faltering just added to a growing retreat from the stock market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The excitement surrounding Facebook’s initial public offering was enough for Alex Tsesis, a law professor, to give the stock market one more try. But after the company’s stock encountered technical problems then sputtered for three days, he sold his few hundred shares for a $2,200 loss and vowed to end his equity gambles for good.

articles.headline: U.S. Winds Down Longer Benefits for the Unemployed
articles.snippet: In February, Congress phased in a reduction of the number of weeks of extended aid and made it more difficult for states to qualify for the maximum aid, adding a financial burden to the long-term unemployed.
articles.abstract: In February, Congress phased in a reduction of the number of weeks of extended aid and made it more difficult for states to qualify for the maximum aid, adding a financial burden to the long-term unemployed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of out-of-work Americans are receiving their final unemployment checks sooner than they expected, even though Congress renewed extended benefits until the end of the year.

articles.headline: In Far Northwest, a New Border Focus on Latinos
articles.snippet: Many people say the Olympic Peninsula has become an unlikely new frontier in the effort to fight illegal immigration from Latin America.
articles.abstract: Many people say the Olympic Peninsula has become an unlikely new frontier in the effort to fight illegal immigration from Latin America.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORKS, Wash. — The Olympic Peninsula has always felt more like the edge of the world than a mere national boundary.

articles.headline: You Can Change the Channel, but Local News Is the Same
articles.snippet: Agreements in which local TV stations share news operations are seen by the stations as a survival strategy, and by critics as a barrier to competition.
articles.abstract: Agreements in which local TV stations share news operations are seen by the stations as a survival strategy, and by critics as a barrier to competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN ANGELO, Tex. — Call a reporter at the CBS television station here, and it might be an anchor for the NBC station who calls back. Or it might be the news director who runs both stations’ news operations.

articles.headline: Dewey & LeBoeuf Files for Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: The bankruptcy filing is the final chapter in a turbulent period for the law firm, which unraveled after disappointing profits and prodigious debt forced it to slash partners’ salaries.
articles.abstract: The bankruptcy filing is the final chapter in a turbulent period for the law firm, which unraveled after disappointing profits and prodigious debt forced it to slash partners’ salaries.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dewey & LeBoeuf, the law firm crippled by financial miscues and partner defections, filed for bankruptcy on Monday night, punctuating the largest law firm collapse in United States history.

articles.headline: Secret ‘Kill List’ Proves a Test of Obama’s Principles and Will
articles.snippet: President Obama has placed himself at the helm of a top secret process to designate terrorists for kill or capture, reserving the final say on approving lethal action, say current and former aides.
articles.abstract: President Obama has placed himself at the helm of a top secret process to designate terrorists for kill or capture, reserving the final say on approving lethal action, say current and former aides.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — This was the enemy, served up in the latest chart from the intelligence agencies: 15 Qaeda suspects in Yemen with Western ties. The mug shots and brief biographies resembled a high school yearbook layout. Several were Americans. Two were teenagers, including a girl who looked even younger than her 17 years.
articles.byline: By Jo Becker and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Western Nations, Protesting Killings, Expel Syrian Envoys
articles.snippet: The response by the United States and others came as a United Nations official gave credence to suspicions that Syrian pro-government militias, known as shabiha, were at least partly responsible for the killings.
articles.abstract: The response by the United States and others came as a United Nations official gave credence to suspicions that Syrian pro-government militias, known as shabiha, were at least partly responsible for the killings.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The United States joined with 10 other nations to expel top Syrian diplomats on Tuesday, increasing international pressure on President Bashar al-Assad. In Damascus, the United Nations envoy said the uprising had reached “a tipping point” after a massacre of more than 100 villagers, nearly half of them children.

articles.headline: Overall Market Turns Up While Facebook Slides
articles.snippet: Shares of the social networking company are now down 24 percent from their initial public offering earlier this month.
articles.abstract: Shares of the social networking company are now down 24 percent from their initial public offering earlier this month.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as stocks on Wall Street moved solidly higher on Tuesday, shares of Facebook went against the tide, continuing to fall sharply below their initial offering price in what could be a sign that the bottom is yet to come.
